an10.237:1.3@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—

an10.237:1.3@3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.
an10.238:1.3@1@Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aṭṭhikasaññā, puḷavakasaññā, vinīlakasaññā, vipubbakasaññā, vicchiddakasaññā, uddhumātakasaññā—

an10.238:1.3@3@The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, a skeleton, a worm-infested corpse, a livid corpse, a split open corpse, and a bloated corpse.
an10.34:1.8@1@paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṁ vūpakāsetuṁ vā vūpakāsāpetuṁ vā;
an10.34:1.8@3@They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
an10.35:1.8@1@paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṁ vūpakāsetuṁ vā vūpakāsāpetuṁ vā;
an10.35:1.8@3@They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
an10.36:1.8@1@paṭibalo hoti anabhiratiṁ vūpakāsetuṁ vā vūpakāsāpetuṁ vā;
an10.36:1.8@3@They’re able to settle dissatisfaction or get someone else to do so.
an10.56:1.3@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā—

an10.56:1.3@3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering, giving up, fading away, and cessation.
an10.57:1.3@1@Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aṭṭhikasaññā, puḷavakasaññā, vinīlakasaññā, vicchiddakasaññā, uddhumātakasaññā—

an10.57:1.3@3@The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, a skeleton, a worm-infested corpse, a livid corpse, a split open corpse, and a bloated corpse.
an10.60:11.1@1@Katamā cānanda, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā?
an10.60:11.1@3@And what is the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world?
an10.60:11.3@1@Ayaṁ vuccatānanda, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā.
an10.60:11.3@3@This is called the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world.
an10.60:3.2@1@Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, asubhasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, pahānasaññā, virāgasaññā, nirodhasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, sabbasaṅkhāresu anicchāsaññā, ānāpānassati.

an10.60:3.2@3@The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, ugliness, drawbacks, giving up, fading away, cessation, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence of all conditions, and mindfulness of breathing.
an10.60:3.2@4@anabhiratasaññā → anabhiratisaññā (mr)
an10.66:2.14@1@Anabhiratiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ.
an10.66:2.14@3@When you’re dissatisfied, this is the kind of suffering you can expect.
an10.66:2.2@1@“Anabhirati kho, āvuso, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye dukkhā, abhirati sukhā.
an10.66:2.2@3@“Reverend, in this teaching and training dissatisfaction is suffering and satisfaction is happiness.
an10.66:2.3@1@Anabhiratiyā, āvuso, sati idaṁ dukkhaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ—
an10.66:2.3@3@When you’re dissatisfied, you can expect this kind of suffering.

an10.88:1.3@1@Anadhigataṁ nādhigacchati, adhigatā parihāyati, saddhammassa na vodāyanti, saddhammesu vā adhimāniko hoti anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṁ carati, aññataraṁ vā saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjati, gāḷhaṁ vā rogātaṅkaṁ phusati, ummādaṁ vā pāpuṇāti cittakkhepaṁ, sammūḷho kālaṁ karoti, kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.

an10.88:1.3@3@They don’t achieve the unachieved. What they have achieved falls away. They don’t refine their good qualities. They overestimate their good qualities, or lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or commit a corrupt offense, or contract a severe illness, or go mad and lose their mind. They feel lost when they die. And when their body breaks up, after death, they are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
an11.6:2.6@1@anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṁ carati,
an11.6:2.6@3@Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an11.6:4.6@1@anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṁ carati,
an11.6:4.6@3@Or they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an4.163:2.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī;

an4.163:2.2@3@It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,
an4.163:2.2@4@paṭikūlasaññī → paṭikkūlasaññī (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed) | anabhiratisaññī → anabhiratasaññī (bj, sya-all, km, pts1ed)
an4.163:3.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī;

an4.163:3.2@3@It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,
an4.169:2.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.

an4.169:2.2@3@It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,
an4.169:3.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.

an4.169:3.2@3@It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions,
an5.121:3.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī, maraṇasaññā kho panassa ajjhattaṁ sūpaṭṭhitā hoti.

an5.121:3.2@3@It’s when a mendicant meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, observes the impermanence of all conditions, and has well established the perception of their own death.
an5.121:3.2@4@anabhiratasaññī → sabbatthapi evameva

an5.122:2.2@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno ajjhattaññeva sati sūpaṭṭhitā hoti dhammānaṁ udayatthagāminiyā paññāya, asubhānupassī kāye viharati, āhāre paṭikūlasaññī, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññī, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassī.

an5.122:2.2@3@It’s when a mendicant has well established mindfulness inside themselves in order to understand the arising and passing away of phenomena, meditates observing the ugliness of the body, perceives the repulsiveness of food, perceives dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observes the impermanence of all conditions.

an5.128:1.3@1@Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena cīvarena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena piṇḍapātena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena senāsanena, asantuṭṭho hoti itarītarena gilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārena, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carati.
an5.128:1.3@3@It’s when a mendicant is not content with any kind of robe, almsfood, lodging, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And they lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
an5.226:1.7@1@otiṇṇacittassetaṁ pāṭikaṅkhaṁ: ‘anabhirato vā brahmacariyaṁ carissati aññataraṁ vā saṅkiliṭṭhaṁ āpattiṁ āpajjissati sikkhaṁ vā paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissati’.

an5.226:1.7@3@When your mind is swamped by lust, you can expect that you will lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or commit one of the corrupt offenses, or resign the training and return to a lesser life.
an5.303:1.3@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā—
an5.303:1.3@3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, drawbacks, repulsiveness of food, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.
an5.303:1.3@4@anabhiratasaññā → sabbatthapi evameva
an5.304:1.3@1@Aniccasaññā, anattasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā—
an5.304:1.3@3@The perceptions of impermanence, not-self, death, repulsiveness of food, and dissatisfaction with the whole world.

an5.56:1.2@1@“etarahi me, bhante, madhurakajāto ceva kāyo, disā ca me na pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca maṁ nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā”ti.

an5.56:1.2@3@“Now, sir, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”

an5.56:2.3@1@‘etarahi me, bhante, madhurakajāto ceva kāyo, disā ca maṁ na pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca me nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, atthi ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti.

an5.56:2.3@3@‘Now, sir, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.’”

an5.56:3.1@1@“Evañhetaṁ, bhikkhu, hoti indriyesu aguttadvārassa, bhojane amattaññuno, jāgariyaṁ ananuyuttassa, avipassakassa kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ, pubbarattāpararattaṁ bodhipakkhiyānaṁ dhammānaṁ bhāvanānuyogaṁ ananuyuttassa viharato, yaṁ madhurakajāto ceva kāyo hoti, disā cassa na pakkhāyanti, dhammā ca taṁ nappaṭibhanti, thinamiddhañcassa cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati, anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carati, hoti cassa dhammesu vicikicchā.

an5.56:3.1@3@“That’s how it is, mendicant, when your sense doors are unguarded, you eat too much, you’re not dedicated to wakefulness, you’re unable to discern skillful qualities, and you don’t pursue the development of the qualities that lead to awakening in the evening and toward dawn. Your body feels like it’s drugged. You’re disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill your mind. You lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.
an5.61:1.3@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, ādīnavasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā—

an7.48:2.2@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā.
an7.48:2.2@3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering.
an7.49:1.3@1@Asubhasaññā, maraṇasaññā, āhāre paṭikūlasaññā, sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, aniccasaññā, anicce dukkhasaññā, dukkhe anattasaññā.
an7.49:1.3@3@The perceptions of ugliness, death, repulsiveness of food, dissatisfaction with the whole world, impermanence, suffering in impermanence, and not-self in suffering.
an7.49:8.1@1@‘Sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti, iti kho panetaṁ vuttaṁ.

an7.49:8.1@3@‘When the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. It culminates in freedom from death and ends in freedom from death.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
an7.49:8.3@1@Sabbaloke anabhiratasaññāparicitena, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cetasā bahulaṁ viharato lokacitresu cittaṁ patilīyati …pe…
an7.49:8.3@3@When a mendicant often meditates with a mind reinforced with the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world, their mind draws back from the world’s shiny things. …

an7.49:8.5@1@Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sabbaloke anabhiratasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṁ viharato lokacitresu cittaṁ patilīyati patikuṭati pativattati, na sampasāriyati upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti.
an7.49:9.1@1@Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sabbaloke anabhiratasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṁ viharato lokacitresu cittaṁ anusandahati appaṭikulyatā saṇṭhāti;
an7.49:9.2@1@veditabbametaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘abhāvitā me sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, natthi me pubbenāparaṁ viseso, appattaṁ me bhāvanābalan’ti.
an7.49:9.4@1@Sace pana, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno sabbaloke anabhiratasaññāparicitena cetasā bahulaṁ viharato lokacitresu cittaṁ patilīyati …pe… upekkhā vā pāṭikulyatā vā saṇṭhāti;
an7.49:9.5@1@veditabbametaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā ‘subhāvitā me sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, atthi me pubbenāparaṁ viseso, pattaṁ me bhāvanābalan’ti.
an7.49:9.7@1@‘Sabbaloke anabhiratasaññā, bhikkhave, bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā amatogadhā amatapariyosānā’ti,
an7.51:4.10@1@Itthatte, bhikkhave, anabhiratā sattā purisesu visaṁyogaṁ gatā.
an7.51:4.10@3@Sentient beings who do not relish their femininity are not yoked to men.
an7.51:4.5@1@Sā tattha arattā tatra anabhiratā bahiddhā purisindriyaṁ na manasi karoti—
an7.51:4.5@3@So she doesn’t focus on the masculinity of others:
an7.51:4.8@1@Sā tattha arattā tatra anabhiratā bahiddhā saṁyogaṁ nākaṅkhati.
an7.51:4.8@3@So she doesn’t desire to yoke herself to another.
an7.51:5.4@1@So tattha aratto tatra anabhirato bahiddhā itthindriyaṁ na manasi karoti—
an7.51:5.4@3@So he doesn’t focus on the femininity of others:
an7.51:5.7@1@So tattha aratto tatra anabhirato bahiddhā saṁyogaṁ nākaṅkhati.
an7.51:5.7@3@So he doesn’t desire to yoke himself to another.
an7.51:5.9@1@Purisatte, bhikkhave, anabhiratā sattā itthīsu visaṁyogaṁ gatā.
an7.51:5.9@3@Sentient beings who do not relish their masculinity are not yoked to women.

dn1:2.4.1@3@But after staying there all alone for a long time, they become dissatisfied and anxious:

mn50:18.5@1@Etha, tumhe, bhikkhave, asubhānupassino kāye viharatha, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino’ti.

mn50:18.5@3@Come, all you mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.’

mn50:19.1@1@Atha kho te, pāpima, bhikkhū kakusandhena bhagavatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena evaṁ ovadiyamānā evaṁ anusāsiyamānā araññagatāpi rukkhamūlagatāpi suññāgāragatāpi asubhānupassino kāye vihariṁsu, āhāre paṭikūlasaññino, sabbaloke anabhiratisaññino, sabbasaṅkhāresu aniccānupassino.

mn50:19.1@3@When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.
mn89:12.4@1@‘addhā ime āyasmanto anabhiratā vā brahmacariyaṁ caranti, atthi vā tesaṁ kiñci pāpaṁ kammaṁ kataṁ paṭicchannaṁ;
mn89:12.4@3@‘Clearly these venerables lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, or they’re hiding some bad deed they’ve done.

sn22.84:1.3@1@“api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo; disāpi me na pakkhāyanti; dhammāpi maṁ na paṭibhanti; thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati; anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carāmi; hoti ca me dhammesu vicikicchā”ti.

sn22.84:1.3@3@“Reverends, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t spring to mind, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”

sn22.84:2.3@1@‘api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo; disāpi me na pakkhāyanti; dhammāpi maṁ na paṭibhanti; thinamiddhañca me cittaṁ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati; anabhirato ca brahmacariyaṁ carāmi; hoti ca me dhammesu vicikicchā’”ti.
sn46.70:0.3@1@Anabhiratisutta
sn46.70:0.3@3@Dissatisfaction
sn46.70:0.3@4@Anabhiratisutta → sabbaloke anabhiratasuttāni (bj)
sn46.70:1.1@1@“Sabbaloke anabhiratisaññā, bhikkhave …pe…”
sn46.70:1.1@3@“Mendicants, when the perception of dissatisfaction with the whole world is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial. …”
sn46.70:1.1@4@anabhiratisaññā → anabhiratasaññā (bj)
sn46.76:4.2@1@Paṭikūlaanabhiratena;
sn46.76:4.2@4@Paṭikūlaanabhiratena → paṭikkūlānabhiratā (bj); paṭikūlena ca sabbaloke (sya-all); paṭikkūla anabhiratena (pts1ed)

sn56.42:3.3@1@Te jātisaṁvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, jarāsaṁvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, maraṇasaṁvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṁvattanikesu saṅkhāresu anabhiratā, jātisaṁvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, jarāsaṁvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, maraṇasaṁvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsasaṁvattanikepi saṅkhāre nābhisaṅkharonti.
sn56.42:3.3@3@Since they don’t take pleasure in such choices, they stop making them.
sn56.43:4.3@1@anabhiratā …pe… nābhisaṅkharonti …pe…
sn56.43:4.3@3@They stop making such choices …
sn56.46:4.3@1@anabhiratā …pe… nābhisaṅkharonti …pe…
sn56.46:4.3@3@They stop making such choices …
sn8.1:1.10@1@Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso attanāva attano anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādetvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.1:1.10@3@Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
sn8.1:1.5@1@Atha kho āyasmato vaṅgīsassa tā itthiyo disvā anabhirati uppajjati, rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
sn8.1:1.5@3@When Vaṅgīsa saw them he became dissatisfied, with lust infecting his mind.
sn8.1:1.8@1@yassa me anabhirati uppannā, rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti, taṁ kutettha labbhā, yaṁ me paro anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādeyya.
sn8.1:1.8@3@that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?
sn8.1:1.9@1@Yannūnāhaṁ attanāva attano anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādeyyan”ti.
sn8.1:1.9@3@Why don’t I do it myself?”
sn8.2:1.3@1@Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa anabhirati uppannā hoti, rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
sn8.2:1.3@3@And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.
sn8.2:1.6@1@yassa me anabhirati uppannā, rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti; taṁ kutettha labbhā, yaṁ me paro anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādeyya.
sn8.2:1.6@3@that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How is it possible for someone else to dispel my discontent and give rise to satisfaction?
sn8.2:1.7@1@Yannūnāhaṁ attanāva attano anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādeyyan”ti.
sn8.2:1.7@3@Why don’t I do it myself?”
sn8.2:1.8@1@Atha kho āyasmā vaṅgīso attanāva attano anabhiratiṁ vinodetvā abhiratiṁ uppādetvā tāyaṁ velāyaṁ imā gāthāyo abhāsi:
sn8.2:1.8@3@Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own discontent and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
sn8.4:1.3@1@Tena kho pana samayena āyasmato vaṅgīsassa anabhirati uppannā hoti, rāgo cittaṁ anuddhaṁseti.
sn8.4:1.3@3@And at that time Venerable Vaṅgīsa became dissatisfied, as lust infected his mind.
dhp186:0@1@Anabhiratabhikkhuvatthu
thag10.7:8.3@1@Lokamhi ca anabhiratiṁ,
thag10.7:8.3@3@and dissatisfaction with the whole world—
ud2.10:2.4@1@“nissaṁsayaṁ kho, āvuso, āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto anabhirato brahmacariyaṁ carati,
ud2.10:2.4@3@“Without a doubt, Venerable Bhaddiya leads the spiritual life dissatisfied.
ud2.10:3.4@1@Nissaṁsayaṁ kho, bhante, āyasmā bhaddiyo kāḷīgodhāya putto anabhirato brahmacariyaṁ carati.
ud3.2:1.4@1@“anabhirato ahaṁ, āvuso, brahmacariyaṁ carāmi;
ud3.2:1.4@3@“I lead the spiritual life dissatisfied.
ud3.2:2.3@1@‘anabhirato ahaṁ, āvuso, brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’”ti.
ud3.2:5.2@1@‘anabhirato ahaṁ, āvuso, brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī’”ti?
ud3.2:5.2@3@you are unable to keep up the spiritual life; that you shall resign the training and return to a lesser life?”
ud3.2:6.1@1@“Kissa pana tvaṁ, nanda, anabhirato brahmacariyaṁ carasi, na sakkosi brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissasī”ti?
ud3.2:6.1@3@“But why are you so dissatisfied with the spiritual life?”
ud3.2:6.4@1@So kho ahaṁ, bhante, tamanussaramāno anabhirato brahmacariyaṁ carāmi, na sakkomi brahmacariyaṁ sandhāretuṁ, sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattissāmī”ti.
ud3.2:6.4@3@Recalling that, I am dissatisfied and shall resign the training.”
